bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to the Director of Sanitation, San Juan Puerto Rico, November 10, 1915

div1.p: Carter recommends a campaign to eliminate mosquitoes.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to the Director of Sanitation, San Juan Puerto Rico, November 10, 1915
div1.opener:
GOVERNMENT OF PORTO RICO
SANITATION SERVICE
OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR
???
San Juan, P. R., November 10th, , 1915
ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS
TO THE
DIRECTOR OF SANITATION
Hon. Director of Sanitation,
San Juan, Porto Rico.
Sir:
div1.p:
Confirming my verbal communication this morning
to the Governor I would repeat to you my recommendation
for a campaign for the elimination of Stegomyia mosquitoes
from San Juan. I scarcely know how to put this matter
strongly enough. With this mosquito prevalent it is
scarcely within the limits of possibility for the city to
ultimately escape an epidemic of Yellow Fever.

Unlike ports in the United States which are infect-
able by Yellow Fever for only a few months in the year,
this place is infectable the whole year around; these
mosquitoes being always active here. It is proportionally
more exposed.

No system of maritime quarantine economically
allowable by commercial interests can be depended on to
absolutely exclude the introduction of Yellow Fever for
an indefinite period of time.
Our safety then must lay in putting the city in such a
condition that this disease will not spread even if
introduced.

Once introduced an epidemic of Yellow Fever would
be a far more serious affair to San Juan than it was in
say-1895. Probably one third of the population is now
susceptible to Yellow Fever. The fever, then, would be
more severe and more wide spread than when its only
victims were foreigners or JIBAROS.
It would also be extremely injurious commercially
from the quarantines which would be laid by the United
States and Cuban ports against this city.

It seems extremely advisable then to put San Juan
in such a condition that Yellow Fever can not spread even
if introduced and to do this we must control the product-
ion of Stegomyia mosquitoes. The costo of so doing is
only insurance and cheap insurance at that.

I will add that the same measures necessary for the
elimination of these mosquitoes will, with possibly slight
addition, also control the production of Culex quinqui
fasciatus (fatigans), believed to be with Stegomyia the cause
of Dengue, so that both diseases would be controled by the
same measures; the insect carriers of both being distinctly
domestic mosquitoes.

Also the elimination of mosquitoes will add much
to the attractions of San Juan as a pleasure resort and
would from this stand point alone be well worth doing.
At any rate work of the same kind has been financed
and carried out by Honolulu and that city considers itself
abundantly repaid in the increased tourist travel, independent-
ly of the matter of health.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, (signed) H. R. Carter,
Asst. Surgeon General of the
U. S. P.H. S. C/fm.
A TRUE COPY.
FM.
